Award.AwardTitle: The Evolution of Science Policy in the United States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The size of the U.S. scientific R&D and innovation enterprise and its economic importance have grown enormously in the post-World War Two era. The complexity of the issues facing science policymakers has increased proportionately, requiring more sophisticated methods and techniques to support decision-making. Recognizing these developments, in 2005, John Marburger, science advisor to President George W. Bush, called on the members of the science and innovation policy community to apply the latest scientific methods in order to make their research more rigorous and systematic. In response, the National Science Foundation (NSF), which has long been a focus such work, established the Science of Science and Innovation Policy (SciSIP) program. SciSIP builds on NSF's fifty-plus year history of science and innovation policy studies. Beginning in the mid-1960s, NSF established programs aimed at cultivating science policy research and teaching at academic institutions. Later, in the mid-1970s, it created a Division of Policy Research and Analysis (PRA) to conduct and support studies of the social returns to R&D. The results of PRA and related programs provide an intellectual background for the practice of science and innovation policy. This project strengthens the management and direction of the SciSIP program and its impact by providing a better understanding of its genesis and broader scientific context. It is also helping to build a stronger foundation for both graduate and undergraduate education in science and innovation policy.

Drawing on unpublished archival materials, published sources, interviews and correspondence, this project examines the range of past science and innovation policy research programs, their strengths and weaknesses, and their contributions to policy and to the development of the field. The project is looking at how NSF and other agencies laid the foundations of U.S. science and innovation policy research, how institutional support was used to seed academic science policy programs and build capacity both inside and outside of the federal government, and finally, how the advent of SciSIP has affected the course of science and innovation policy research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The environment for scientific research in the U.S. is shaped to a considerable extent by policies of the federal government. Those policies have long been based on the judgment and opinions of policymakers and committees of experts. As science and science-based technology play an ever-greater role in our globalized society, it is essential that science and technology (S&T) policies be based not just on opinions and expert judgment, but also on empirical research -- on data, evidence, and analysis. The growth of research intended to support evidence-based S&T policies in the U.S., mainly in universities, is the subject of this project.

The framework for S&T policy in the United States was established in the wake of the Second World War by a 1945 report called Science: The Endless Frontier prepared by Vannevar Bush, one of the key figures of wartime science. Some years later, in the late 1950s and early 1960s, S&T policy began to be seen as a subject of serious academic study. Motivated in part by the Soviet Union’s launch of Sputnik in October 1957, a number of universities established programs of research and education in S&T policy attracting scholars in economics, political science, engineering, and other fields. Around the same time, the National Science Foundation (NSF) began a small program in university science policy and planning. In December 1967, representatives of many of the academic programs came together to form a “Science and Public Policy Studies Group” with assistance from the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS). Faculty in these programs and elsewhere in the academic world, as well as their students and practitioners in government and associations, fueled the growth of S&T policy studies as a profession. Although the original NSF science policy and planning program disappeared after a few years, the development of S&T policy studies in academia through the 1970s and 1980s was fostered by the emergence of other federal programs, including NSF’s program in Policy Research and Analysis (PRA, which soon gained the status of a division), as well as programs in the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and NASA, and funding from private foundations, especially the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation.

NSF, however, lost much of its enthusiasm for S&T policy research in the early 1990s as a result of a widely-distributed but flawed PRA study that was touted by NSF’s director and sharply criticized by a congressional subcommittee. Partially as a result of this experience, PRA was dissolved in 1995 and the next decade saw little explicit federal support for S&T policy research.

John H. Marburger III, a physicist and university administrator, serving as science advisor to President George W. Bush, sparked renewed interest in S&T policy research when, in a May 2005 speech, he lamented the lack of the tools he needed to advise the President on science issues and to steer the federal science establishment in his role as director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy. Marburger’s speech and his staff’s follow-up efforts led to the creation of the “Science of Science and Innovation Policy” (SciSIP) program at NSF. SciSIP has been investing in the development and application of new S&T policy tools, methodologies, and datasets utilizing recent advances in data science, computer technology, and software. The program has spawned several new institutions, opening the field to new ideas, and expanding the horizon of S&T policy. If SciSIP and its progeny succeed, they may well herald a new era of empirical, evidence-based science and technology policy. It is hoped that the present study will contribute to understanding of these efforts and the background from which they emerged.
